Title: Great idea, terrible execution.
Review:
The Game isn't terrible, it has top notch acting from both Douglas, Penn and Unger. However there's a reason this is deserving of a 5 and not an 8 or 9.

I can only suspend my disbelief so far and The Game is about a mile beyond that, the original idea of a man who is bored of life's activities intrigued enough to sign up for a "game" without any idea what it's about. However, the execution of said idea is about as ridiculous as Stalone and De Niro making a boxing movie in 2013.

Okay first off, 53 year old Michael Douglas would most likely die from the stunts his character performs in the movie. The first likely death or serious injury of Douglas would have occurred in the first adventure where they have to fall what looks like 25-30 feet into metal garbage bins, better have good aim considering they looked to be about 4x5 feet. Next,the taxi bail into the body of water according to Christine they had a safety net, except how long would it take to pull out a full cab of water, most likely long enough for him to drown. I'll skip the minor possibilities and go right to the most ridiculous part, the end, so Douglas shoots his brother with what i assume is a blank because they showed his chest, after shooting his brother he jumps off the building and happens to land perfectly on the target they had set up, lucky he walked off the perfect spot of the building, also lucky he didn't have a heart attack on the way down which is common for people jumping off skyscrapers, also also lucky he landed o the target zone on his back or chest and not his neck.

Anyways not a terrible movie but a little bit silly for me.

Title: Could have been so much more
Review:
I just rented this movie through Redbox, didn't realize it was so old.

This movie could have had some fixes to make it more believable or at least for the viewer to have a little more buy-in on what happens to Nicholas Van Orton.

Spoiler - Nobody can possibly believe that other people can strategize each move that another would make so that they could stay ahead of them - unless it was a dream or a matrix like situation where none of it is real anyway and completely concocted from software. For instance, what if while he is taking his tests in the beginning, they pull him into a virtual reality, which we don't know about until the end, which is "the game" - rather than trying to convince the audience it was real.

Second, there wasn't enough character development in the beginning for anybody to care what happens to this guy or what issues he has beyond being a cold workaholic to understand why the game is laid out as it is. If we knew he was afraid of heights or of suicide, or of failing to be perfect, the things occurring to him might seem more intense. (such as jumping off the fire escape into the trash cans, being trapped in an elevator, having his briefcase not open up when needed, etc.)

Title: Worked well for entertaining a guest.. great suspense flick.
Review:
Just saw this maybe my 4th or 5th time and it finally lost its luster for me. But the guest for whom we recommended it was stoked: "Oh, this movie!" by the third reel. What is it about this flick that makes it so entertaining the first time? Of course the reason is that it's a mystery. (see Library > Mystery Section)

Notorious loose cannon, boomer liberal Sean Penn (and the feeling that friend Louise Ciccone is in the wings) dominates his character, the smaller part of Conrad, who touches his virtually opposite brother Nicholas (Michael Douglass) suggesting he change his straight laced ways. Both apparently are filthy rich, but only Conrad has grown up, according to these outre, dramatist-based rules for emotional growth: maturity according to dramatists.

The film comes from this place, like a Madonna concert, like most dramatists. It wants us to out our sexuality, or whatever else might be holding us back from being a free, more gregarious and therefore more honest spirit--usually vanity, and that is true for Nicholas, as is briefly shown when he sees himself in the mirror. All dramatists hate vanity. As well, I guess, since it's so important to hide vanity in order to keep up appearances. Trust me, you wont be able to hide, once dramatists have their eyes on you. Funny.

Like a Madonna song, the message behind the movie is: Respect Yourself. According to dramatists and other folks who rely on gregarious behavior to succeed in life, all quiet and otherwise shy wallflowers need to be changed if they are ever to fully enjoy life. Granted, not all quiet people are vain power brokers. Nonetheless, the dramatist's (movie gen's) credo is clear, at least how it appears to be fueling the message within this film. Which is a movie gen icon, if nothing else.

Enter: 90s EFX: feature film special effects units, the state-of-the-art. If the EFX culture had a heart, and wanted to share a message with the world, this would be its story. It's dramatists again, after all. Like athletes, or Jack La Lane, they want you to out your stuff, too, to "give it up" and become a stronger, more sociable person. See, I knew there were adolescent girls behind this, and frankly I don't mind that. Don't mind being reminded that I need to get out more, be more sociable. Almost as good as having my own daughter, watching action flicks like this. Maybe this movie was a little bit smarter daughter, though. Def smarter than most action films.

Title: Suspenseful and Thought-provoking.
Review: I saw David Fincher's The Game last night on TNT and have to say it was for the most part a pretty satisfying experience, although as others have noted, the ending, which I won't give away, does not exactly fit the preceding two hours or so, because it has a bit of a cop-out, wrong-note, life-affirming sort of feel to it. Michael Douglas, who has emerged as perhaps Hollywood's best lead actor in the middle-years range, gives one of his most impressive performances. He plays a wealthy San Francisco investment banker here, but while this guy may be as corporate-greedy as Gordon Gekko in Oliver Stone's socially concerned Wall Street (1987), Nick Van Orton is a character you can sympathize with as his wayward younger brother, played by Sean Penn, tempts him to re-awaken a side of himself that his life as a powerful capitalist has apparently deadened. The thing that is supposed to change his life is The Game, an experience custom-tailored to participants by a nebulous corporation called Consumer Recreation Services (CRS). Van Orton's curiosity impels him to submit to CRS's psychological and physical testing without even knowing what the exact nature of The Game---its rules, its object---actually is. In a scene alluding to Kubrick's 1971 version of Anthony Burgess' 1962 novel A Clockwork Orange, Van Orton is stuck in a dark projection room being fed an endless series of unrelated images interlaced on the screen with suggestive words. Before he knows it, Van Orton is plunged into a non-stop sequence of experiences, more life-threatening than life-enhancing as his brother had promised, precipitated by the pretty good Deborah Unger as Christine, a waitress at a swanky restaurant. As Van Orton is confronted by a series of weird events, such as finding a life-sized clown doll lying on its stomach on the drive outside his mansion, an image deliberately designed to evoke for him the childhood memory of seeing his father commit suicide by throwing himself off their roof, he begins to question whether CRS is really in the private entertainment industry or has he been set up. Is CRS some kind of scam designed to bilk him of his fortune? Can he trust Christine, who is thrown into the non-stop action along with him? Is his brother in on it, too? Fincher's breathless direction keeps you riveted to your seat waiting to find out how this will all be wrapped up. Proof that this picture is so engrossing for a wide array of tastes is that I saw it at my mom's and she ended up enjoying it as much as I did, even though I took her to see last year's Fight Club, also by Fincher, and she ended up walking out of the theater by the end of the first half hour of that picture, saying, "I'll wait for you outside. This is disgusting." Well, I loved 1999's Fight Club, which was much better than the ridiculously overrated American Beauty, and for me, after having seen The Game, I think Fincher is in the top handful of the best Hollywood directors to come out of the last decade. While The Game is not as darkly subversive as Fight Club, it explores some of the same themes and concerns, such as the emotional emptiness and social disconnectedness engendered by the single-minded pursuit of wealth and the need to find something drastically outside the "mainstream" in order to get back in touch with the primordial self, as well as the paranoia unleashed by the rapid pace of computer technological change. For people who say that the somewhat sappy wrap-up at the end makes them feel "cheated," they ought to consider that this movie makes you think while at the same time taking you for a rip-rollicking, good suspenseful-thriller ride. Not too many movies come along all that often that can do that.

Title: Slick, ominous, suspenseful and compelling
Review:
The first time I saw this movie I was disappointed in the ending. That wasn't because the ending was an anti-climax - far from it. On the contrary, maybe it was the fact that the first seven eighths of the movie was so impressive.

The movie exhibits all the cinematic style and flair of Director David Fincher's other efforts; viewers will notice the use of murky lighting and largely night-time scenes used in Fincher's successors, "Seven", "Fight Club" and "Panic Room" to create a unique brand of menace and suspense. While "The Game" contains the necessary plot twists and the application of Michael Douglas in this role is a case of casting perfection, the film does not quite carry off the synergy of plot and direction towards as powerful a conclusion as, say, that in Fight Club.

But I AM being picky here. The pace is far from inert; there is plenty of action and there is more than enough happening in the story to keep you in suspense without requiring much concentration from the viewer.

Despite the odd (minor) errors in continuity and the final scenes making a rather hurried attempt to tie some of the pieces together (and answer your questions) there is rather little to criticise. If this is your first time, chances are you won't pick the ending, but it almost seems as though you weren't meant to in the first place. Sean Penn turns in a commendable, dynamic role as Douglas' brother in the film, and there are no overt blemishes in the acting of the other characters.

If you're not desperately after the mind-warping in-your-face vivacity of Fight Club but you want a little more substance; a more satisfying and climactic ending than that of Panic Room, you can't go wrong here.

Title: Incredible psycho-thriller
Review:
The Game begins slowly and builds up suspense as more pieces get set into place. Michael Douglas is excellent, Sean Penn is convincing (you won't hear me say that often) and the rest of the supporting cast is excellent. The ending is a surprise, but consistent. Nicholas Van Horton (Michael Douglas) is a wealthy investment banker. On his 48th birthday (the same age his father committed suicide) his brother (Sean Penn) gives him a coupon for CRS (Consumer Recreation Services), a company that gives bored rich people the experience of a lifetime. And so it begins. By the time you reach the end, anything is possible. The ending is a surprise, but consistent, and different than many other movies in the genre. This ranks in the top ten with me.
